member.name: P:HttpFs.Client.HttpFsState.empty
member.summary: Will re-generate random CLR per-app-domain -- create your own state for deterministic boundary generation (or anything else needing random).

member.name: P:HttpFs.Client.Response.expectedEncoding
member.summary: A Uri that contains the URI of the Internet resource that responded to the request. <see cref="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.httpwebresponse.responseuri%28v=vs.110%29.aspx"/>.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.CookieName
member.summary: The name (key) of a cookie. The string value is unencoded.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.Form
member.summary: You often pass form-data to the server, e.g. curl -X POST <url> -F k=v -F file1=@file.png

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FormData.NameValue
member.summary: Use when you simply post form data

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FormData.MultipartMixed
member.summary: Use when you post multiple files as a multi-file-browse control Will use: multipart/mixed inside a multipart/form-data.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FormData.FormFile
member.summary: Use when you post a single file Will use: multipart/form-data

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FormData
member.summary: http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/interact/forms.html

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.File
member.summary: A file is a file name, a content-type (application/octet-stream if unknown) and the data.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FileName
member.summary: An optional file name

member.name: P:HttpFs.Client.ContentDisposition.exts
member.summary: e.g. "name=user_name"

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.ContentDisposition
member.summary: http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec19.html section 19.5.1 Content-Disposition, BNF.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.QueryStringValue
member.summary: The string value is not yet encoded.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.QueryStringName
member.summary: The key of a query string key-value pair. The string value is not yet encoded.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FormValue
member.summary: The string value is not yet encoded.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.FormEntryName
member.summary: The key you have in <input name="key" ... /> This string value is not yet encoded.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.getResponse(HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Sends the HTTP request and returns the full response as a Response record, asynchronously.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Client.DuplicateHeader
member.summary: The header you tried to add was already there, see issue #64.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.responseAsBytes(HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Note: this sends the request, reads the response, disposes it and its stream

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.responseAsString(HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Note: this sends the request, reads the response, disposes it and its stream

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.timeout(System.Int32,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: TODO: use as filter instead (composition)

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.keepAlive(System.Boolean,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary:
Sets the keep-alive header. Defaults to true.
If true, Connection header also set to 'Keep-Alive' If false, Connection header also set to 'Close'
NOTE: If true, headers only sent on first request.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.proxy(HttpFs.Client.Proxy,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary:
Sends the request via the provided proxy.
If this is no set, the proxy settings from IE will be used, if available.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.responseCharacterEncoding(System.Text.Encoding,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary:
Decodes the response using the specified encoding, regardless of what the response specifies.
If this is not set, response character encoding will be: - taken from the response content-encoding header, if provided, otherwise UTF8
Many web pages define the character encoding in the HTML. This will not be used.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.cookie(HttpFs.Client.Cookie,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary:
Adds a cookie to the request The domain will be taken from the URL, and the path set to '/'.
If your cookie appears not to be getting set, it could be because the response is a redirect, which (by default) will be followed automatically, but cookies will not be re-sent.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.queryStringItem(System.String,System.String,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Adds the provided QueryString record onto the request URL. Multiple items can be appended, but only the last appended key/value with the same key as a previous key/value will be used.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.bodyStringEncoded(System.String,System.Text.Encoding,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Sets the request body, using the provided character encoding.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.bodyString(System.String,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary:
Sets the the request body, using UTF-8 character encoding.
Only certain request types should have a body, e.g. Posts.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.body(HttpFs.Client.RequestBody,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Lets you set your own body - use the RequestBody type to build it up.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.autoDecompression(HttpFs.Client.DecompressionScheme,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary:
Sets the accept-encoding request header to accept the decompression methods selected, and automatically decompresses the responses.
Multiple schemes can be OR'd together, e.g. (DecompressionScheme.Deflate ||| DecompressionScheme.GZip)

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.withNTLMAuthentication(System.String,System.String,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Adds a credential cache to support NTLM authentication

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.basicAuthentication(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds an HTTP Basic Authentication header, which includes the username and password encoded as a base-64 string

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.setHeader(HttpFs.Client.RequestHeader,HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Adds a header, defined as a RequestHeader The current implementation doesn't allow you to add a single header multiple times. File an issue if this is a limitation for you.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.autoFollowRedirectsDisabled(HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Disables automatic following of redirects, which is enabled by default

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.cookiesDisabled(HttpFs.Client.Request)
member.summary: Disables cookies, which are enabled by default

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.createUrl(HttpFs.Client.HttpMethod,System.String)
member.summary: The default value is 100,000 milliseconds (100 seconds). <see cref="https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.httpwebrequest.timeout%28v=vs.110%29.aspx"/>.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.RequestModule.create(HttpFs.Client.HttpMethod,System.Uri)
member.summary: Creates the Request record which can be used to make an HTTP request
member.param: The type of request to be made (Get, Post, etc.)
The URL of the resource including protocol, e.g. 'http://www.relentlessdevelopment.net'

member.summary: For those of you who can't be bothered to use getResponse |> Response.readBodyAsString.

member.summary: Uses the HttpWebRequest to get the response. HttpWebRequest throws an exception on anything but a 200-level response, so we handle such exceptions and return the response.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.Impl.uriEncode(System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary:
URI encoding: for each byte in the byte-representation of the string, as seen after encoding with a given `byteEncoding`, print the %xx character as an ASCII character, for transfer.
Pass the byteEncoding -- this is equivalent of the `accept-charset` attribute on the form-element in HTML. If you don't know what to do: pass UTF8 and it will 'just work'.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Client.Impl.StreamWriters.writeUtf8
member.summary: Writes a string as UTF8

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.Impl.StreamWriters.writeLineUtf8(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a string and CRLF as UTF8

member.name: P:HttpFs.Client.Impl.StreamWriters.writeAscii
member.summary: Writes a string as ASCII

member.name: M:HttpFs.Client.Impl.StreamWriters.writeLineAscii(System.String)
member.summary: Writes a string and CRLF as ASCII

member.name: T:HttpFs.Composition
member.summary: Module that encapsulates common compositional patterns

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.CombiningTarget
member.summary: A logger to use for combining a number of other loggers

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LiterateConsoleTarget
member.summary: Logs a line in a format that is great for human consumption, using console colours to enhance readability. Sample: [10:30:49 INF] User "AdamC" began the "checkout" process with 100 cart items

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.LoggingConfig.consoleSemaphore
member.summary: When composing apps from the outside-in (rather than having a unified framework with static/global config) with libraries (again, rather than a unified framework) like is best-practice, there's not necessarily a way to coordinate around the STDOUT and STDERR streams between different libraries running things on different threads. Use Logary's adapter to replace this semaphore with a global semaphore.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.LoggingConfig.getLogger
member.summary: The `getLogger` function returns a logger that directly can be logged to.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.LoggingConfig.timestamp
member.summary: The `timestamp` function should preferably be monotonic and not 'jumpy' or take much time to call.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Logger.logWithAck(HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel,HttpFs.Logging.Message})
member.summary: Evaluates the callback if the log level is enabled. Returns an async that itself completes when the logging infrastructure has finished writing that Message. Completes directly if nothing is logged. What the ack means from a durability standpoint depends on the logging infrastructure you're using behind this facade. Will not block, besides doing the computation inside the callback. You should not do blocking operations in the callback.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Logger.logSimple(HttpFs.Logging.Message)
member.summary: Logs the message without awaiting the logging infrastructure's ack of having successfully written the log message. What the ack means from a durability standpoint depends on the logging infrastructure you're using behind this facade.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Logger.log(HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel,HttpFs.Logging.Message})
member.summary: Evaluates the callback if the log level is enabled. Will not block, besides doing the computation inside the callback. You should not do blocking operations in the callback.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.Logger
member.summary: The logger is the interface for calling code to use for logging.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.level
member.summary: How important? See the docs on the LogLevel type for details.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.timestamp
member.summary: When? nanoseconds since UNIX epoch.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.fields
member.summary: The semantic-logging data.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.value
member.summary: The main value for this metric or event. Either a Gauge or an Event. (A discriminated union type)

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.name
member.summary: The 'path' or 'name' of this data point. Do not confuse template in (Event template) = message.value

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.utcTicks
member.summary: Gets the ticks for UTC since 0001-01-01 00:00:00 for this message. You can pass this value into a DateTimeOffset c'tor

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Message.README
member.summary: If you're looking for how to transform the Message's fields, then use the module methods rather than instance methods, since you'll be creating new values rather than changing an existing value.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.Message
member.summary: This is record that is logged. It's capable of representing both metrics (gauges) and events. See https://github.com/logary/logary for details.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.EpochNanoSeconds
member.summary: The # of nanoseconds after 1970-01-01 00:00:00.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.PointValue.Gauge
member.summary: This is as value for a metric, with a unit attached. The unit can be something like Seconds or Hz.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.PointValue.Event
member.summary: An event is what it sounds like; something occurred and needs to be logged. Its field is named 'template' because it should not be interpolated with values; instead these values should be put in the 'fields' field of the Message.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.PointValue
member.summary: Represents a logged value; either a Gauge or an Event.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.Fatal
member.summary: The log message denotes a fatal error which cannot be recovered from. The service should be shut down. Human corrective action is needed.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.Error
member.summary: The log message is at an error level, meaning an unhandled exception occurred at a location where it is deemed important to keeping the service running. A human should take corrective action.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.Warn
member.summary: The log message is a warning; e.g. there was an unhandled exception or an even occurred which was unexpected. Sometimes human corrective action is needed.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.Info
member.summary: The log message is informational; e.g. the service started, stopped or some important business event occurred.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.Debug
member.summary: The log message is at a default level, debug level. Useful for shipping to infrastructure that further processes it, but not so useful for human inspection in its raw format, except during development.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.Verbose
member.summary: The log message is not that important; can be used for intricate debugging.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.toInt
member.summary: Turn the LogLevel into an integer

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.ofString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts the string passed to a Loglevel.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.ofInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Turn an integer into a LogLevel

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel.ToString
member.summary: Converts the LogLevel to a string

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel
member.summary: The log level denotes how 'important' the gauge or event message is.

member.summary: Adds an exception to the Message, to the 'errors' field, inside a list.

member.summary: Sets the value of the field on the log message.

member.summary: Sets the name as a single string; if this string contains dots, the string will be split on these dots.

member.summary: Sets the name/path of the log message.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.MessageModule.gauge(System.Int64,System.String)
member.summary: Create a new instantaneous value in a log message.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.MessageModule.eventX(System.String,HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel)
member.summary: Create a new event log message â€“ like `event` but with parameters flipped. Useful to use with `Logger.log` with point-free style, to reduce the noise. E.g. `logger.logVerbose (eventX "Returned {code}" >> setField "code" 24)`

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.MessageModule.event(HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel,System.String)
member.summary: Create a new event log message.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.MessageModule
member.summary: The Message module contains functions that can help callers compose messages. This module is especially helpful to open to make calls into Logary's facade small.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Log.createHiera(System.String[])
member.summary: Create an hierarchically named logger

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Log.create(System.String)
member.summary: Create a named logger. Full stop (.) acts as segment delimiter in the hierachy of namespaces and loggers.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.Log
member.summary: Module for acquiring static loggers (when you don't want or can't) pass loggers as values.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Targets.create(HttpFs.Logging.LogLevel)
member.summary:
Create a new target. Prefer `Log.create` in your own libraries, or let the composing app replace your target instance through your configuration.
Will log to console (colourised) by default, and also to the output window in your IDE if you specify a level below Info.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.Targets
member.summary: "Shortcut" for creating targets; useful at the top-level configuration point of your library.

member.name: T:HttpFs.Logging.Global.Flyweight
member.summary: The flyweight just references the current configuration. If you want multiple per-process logging setups, then don't use the static methods, but instead pass a Logger instance around, setting the name field of the Message value you pass into the logger.

member.name: M:HttpFs.Logging.Global.initialise(HttpFs.Logging.LoggingConfig)
member.summary: Call from the initialisation of your library. Initialises the Logary.Facade globally/per process.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Global.DefaultConfig
member.summary: The global default configuration, which logs to Console at Info level.

member.name: P:HttpFs.Logging.Global.consoleSemaphore
member.summary: This is the global semaphore for colourising the console output. Ensure that the same semaphore is used across libraries by using the Logary Facade Adapter in the final composing app/service.

member.summary: let the ISO8601 love flow

member.summary: Split a structured message up into theme-able parts (tokens), allowing the final output to display to a user with colours to enhance readability.
